Include summary of condition at discharge.

Avoid generalizations, assumptions, verbose and cumbersome formulations, and redundancy. Do not invent or presume anything. Generally, formulate in the imperfect tense, reported speech from individuals (e.g., from patients) in subjunctive I, and medical assessments and diagnoses in the present tense.
Minimize hallucinations. Do not generate recommendations on your own or add anything. Write nothing about topics for which there is no information basis from the EHR.
Don't include all private information, such as ID and date of birth. Use ___ to represent names of patients and medical professionals.

Date: 2024-02-14

Patient: Mr. ___  
Age: 70  
Gender: Male  
Admission Date: 2024-02-10  
Discharge Date: 2024-02-14  

Dear Mr. ___,

This letter serves as a summary of your hospital stay from February 10, 2024, to February 14, 2024. You were admitted due to a presentation of symptoms including cough, shortness of breath, hemoptysis, and fever. Upon admission, a diagnosis of lobar pneumonia, unspecified organism (ICD-10 Code J18.1), was established. A Chest X-Ray conducted on the day of admission revealed consolidation in the left lower lobe, consistent with pneumonia.

On admission, your vital signs indicated a temperature of 38.5°C, a heart rate of 90 bpm, blood pressure of 130/85 mmHg, a respiratory rate of 20 breaths per minute, and an oxygen saturation level of 92%. Initial laboratory investigations showed elevated inflammatory markers, with a CRP of 60 mg/L and WBC of 12 x10^9/L, suggesting an active infectious process.

Empirical antibiotic therapy was commenced with Amoxicillin IV, 500 mg every 8 hours, alongside symptomatic treatment with Paracetamol as required. Over the subsequent days, your condition showed significant improvement: by February 11, your CRP levels had decreased to 50 mg/L and you exhibited clinical improvement, leading to an adjustment in your antibiotic regimen to a daily dose of Amoxicillin IV, 250 mg. Atorvastatin 20 mg was continued orally each night.

By February 12, your temperature had normalized and your oxygen saturation levels stabilized at 96%. Considering the positive trend, it was planned to transition to oral antibiotics. The following day, you continued to show improvement with CRP levels further declining to 20 mg/L and WBC to 7 x10^9/L. Your clinical condition was sufficiently stable for discharge planning.

You have been discharged in a medically stable condition. At the time of discharge, your vital parameters were within normal limits: temperature at 36.5°C, heart rate at 78 bpm, blood pressure at 118/74 mmHg, respiratory rate at 14 breaths per minute, and oxygen saturation at 98%.

Upon discharge, you are advised to continue oral Amoxicillin at 250 mg daily for an additional five days. Please ensure to take Atorvastatin as previously prescribed, 20 mg once nightly. It is vital that you attend a follow-up appointment at the outpatient clinic in two weeks to monitor your recovery and ensure the complete resolution of the pneumonia.

If you experience any new symptoms or a recurrence of your illness, please do not hesitate to contact your healthcare provider. Wishing you a smooth recovery.

Sincerely,

Dr. ___  
[Hospital Name]  
[Contact Information]
